snippet.textDisplay: How very lucky and fortunate we are to have the Stephen and Jon show.  I'm a relatively new convert, and I've past the half century mark so I do have lots to compare them to, but they consistently blow me away, mostly with their loving, compassionate common sense.  I don't know that we've ever had anything like this show before, in terms of it's willingness to go to these beautiful emotional depths, consistently.  We need authenticity in this world, to show us it actually matters.  And dignity, integrity.  And good for these folks, they give it.  They bare their souls, they give their all, and even when skewering someone there's an air of common sense and compassion, which is really what we need more than anything.  Couldn't ask for better role models, on top of top shelf entertainers!
snippet.textOriginal: How very lucky and fortunate we are to have the Stephen and Jon show.  I'm a relatively new convert, and I've past the half century mark so I do have lots to compare them to, but they consistently blow me away, mostly with their loving, compassionate common sense.  I don't know that we've ever had anything like this show before, in terms of it's willingness to go to these beautiful emotional depths, consistently.  We need authenticity in this world, to show us it actually matters.  And dignity, integrity.  And good for these folks, they give it.  They bare their souls, they give their all, and even when skewering someone there's an air of common sense and compassion, which is really what we need more than anything.  Couldn't ask for better role models, on top of top shelf entertainers!

snippet.textDisplay:
Neil Peart was the drummer and lyricist for the band, RUSH. He, like Kobe, shocking passed away recently. These are some lyrics that always put things in perspective, and have gotten me and many others through some hard times.

"Suddenly, you were gone
From all the lives you left your mark upon" Afterimage

"When we are young
Wandering the face of the earth
Wondering what our dreams might be worth
Learning that we're only immortal
For a limited time" Dreamline

"The measure of a life is a measure of love and respect
So hard to earn so easily burned
The measure of a life is a measure of love and respect
So hard to earn so easily burned
Like the fullness of time
A garden to nurture and protect

In horizon to set of the sun?
To the stars goes spinning
Spinning 'round the night
Oh it is what it is and forever
Each moment of memory of light
The arrow flies while you dream
The hours tick away
The cells tick away
The watchmaker has time up his sleve
The hours tick…" The Garden.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Took the words right out of my mouth! Two families were killed in a  helicopter crash in Hawaii less than a month before Kobe's crash, they were also flying in heavy fog. There was a little girl the same age as Gianna, 13, on that flight as well. I cried when I read the article and I voiced to my boyfriend that it's absolutely crazy how many helicopters crash in Hawaii, and how nothing is being done about it. Then of course, I'm hit with this news and it just took me back to the other story that was upsetting from back in December. I care about people, especially young kids, even if I don't know them. These deaths are preventable!
snippet.textOriginal: Took the words right out of my mouth! Two families were killed in a  helicopter crash in Hawaii less than a month before Kobe's crash, they were also flying in heavy fog. There was a little girl the same age as Gianna, 13, on that flight as well. I cried when I read the article and I voiced to my boyfriend that it's absolutely crazy how many helicopters crash in Hawaii, and how nothing is being done about it. Then of course, I'm hit with this news and it just took me back to the other story that was upsetting from back in December. I care about people, especially young kids, even if I don't know them. These deaths are preventable!

snippet.textDisplay: ANTI-FRAGILE    6:23 "So I hope the NTSB will do something..."  At the risk of trying to offer a correction to Stephen's poignant, loving, and beautiful remarks... as I understand it, the NTSB makes recommendations for safety improvements but the FAA is the giant bureaucracy that makes the cost-benefit analysis of what is (eventually) implemented … Presumably the "cost" of the loss of Kobe Bryant will eventually animate some improvements in safety.  Airplanes are said to be "anti-fragile" exactly because each "accident" is studied, learned from, and ultimately serves to improve safety.   Life is short and ultimately fatal... nobody gets out alive.  We can't afford to eliminate all risk, but can try to make more sane trade-offs between function and safety... ultimately safer but never risk free.
snippet.textOriginal: ANTI-FRAGILE    6:23 "So I hope the NTSB will do something..."  At the risk of trying to offer a correction to Stephen's poignant, loving, and beautiful remarks... as I understand it, the NTSB makes recommendations for safety improvements but the FAA is the giant bureaucracy that makes the cost-benefit analysis of what is (eventually) implemented … Presumably the "cost" of the loss of Kobe Bryant will eventually animate some improvements in safety.  Airplanes are said to be "anti-fragile" exactly because each "accident" is studied, learned from, and ultimately serves to improve safety.   Life is short and ultimately fatal... nobody gets out alive.  We can't afford to eliminate all risk, but can try to make more sane trade-offs between function and safety... ultimately safer but never risk free.

snippet.textDisplay:
A wonderful discussion on the pain, grief, and tragedy that this crash left with those family members, and close friends to the victims in the crash, and with a wise addition of a plea for advancement on the information tech for helicopters to ascertain the problems that can arise to endanger the precious passengers.

This was beautiful Stephen, thank you, while I have not lost family/friends in this manner, this was still clearly heartfelt, and meaningful, and wise, considering others who are just as well meaning, may not consider this aspect of this tragedy to mention and speak on, but it is certainly welcome, and I dearly hope people, including the engineers and companies that produce such helicopters, hear loud and clear.

My prayers for peace, comfort, and solace go to those in pain from the loss of the people in this tragedy, I hope they can find healing and strength in each other and any others willing to help them in this time of grieving.
snippet.textOriginal:
A wonderful discussion on the pain, grief, and tragedy that this crash left with those family members, and close friends to the victims in the crash, and with a wise addition of a plea for advancement on the information tech for helicopters to ascertain the problems that can arise to endanger the precious passengers.

This was beautiful Stephen, thank you, while I have not lost family/friends in this manner, this was still clearly heartfelt, and meaningful, and wise, considering others who are just as well meaning, may not consider this aspect of this tragedy to mention and speak on, but it is certainly welcome, and I dearly hope people, including the engineers and companies that produce such helicopters, hear loud and clear.

My prayers for peace, comfort, and solace go to those in pain from the loss of the people in this tragedy, I hope they can find healing and strength in each other and any others willing to help them in this time of grieving.

snippet.textDisplay: Everytime there is a crash of an aircraft and the NTSB investigates, they provide a final report to the FAA with recommendations to improve the aircraft but the FAA does not take them into account and do not require the life saving devices for such vehicles. What's sad is Kobe's helicopter didn't have any safety devices that the NTSB has recommended for his model but since the FAA doesn't require it, owners don't have it all the time.

snippet.textDisplay: It was so touching to hear Jon tell his story and then listen to how painful a connection this is for both Stephen and Choppy. I cannot imagine how Choppy continues to fly after having lost her son in a helicopter accident and her husband in a plane crash. It is just surreal. Numbs me to think that these families must now live in the constant void of information that could have maybe given them closure. Although, I did read somewhere that the NTSB actually recommended black boxes for helicopters but the FAA rejected those recommendations. I could be wrong. I do know, however, that this recommendation HAS been made. And rejected - which seems entirely unconscionable, as Stephen said.
snippet.textOriginal: It was so touching to hear Jon tell his story and then listen to how painful a connection this is for both Stephen and Choppy. I cannot imagine how Choppy continues to fly after having lost her son in a helicopter accident and her husband in a plane crash. It is just surreal. Numbs me to think that these families must now live in the constant void of information that could have *maybe* given them closure. Although, I did read somewhere that the NTSB actually recommended black boxes for helicopters but the FAA rejected those recommendations. I could be wrong. I do know, however, that this recommendation HAS been made. And rejected - which seems entirely unconscionable, as Stephen said.

snippet.textDisplay:
one of the few/only times i've heard colbert publicly speak of the aircraft tragedy from his own life. as an aircraft nerd, i remember studying the tragedy, only to later find out (after colbert became a celebrity) that his father/brothers were on it https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_Air_Lines_Flight_212
perhaps the only silver lining from aircraft crashes is that they make aviation safer. i hope this is the case in kobe's flight

snippet.textDisplay: Although your sentiment and concern is for the future safety of helicopter pilots and passengers Mr. Colbert...it's not the NTSB that can do anything aside from making recommendations...the trouble lies with the FAA regulators alone!!! snippet.textDisplay: We will always have accidental deaths associated with mechanical transportation, sadly. Not to diminish those losses, but personally I would be more concerned about the mass cancer deaths that will occur due to glyphosate poisoning and other environmental toxins created by the fracking industry, for instance. They continue to be released and accumulate with virtually no regulation.

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you Stephen for disclosing your own loss and agony and for using your position to encourage a change to create better helicopter safety.  I too lost my father in a plane accident, happened to be a small Navy plane on July 7 1953.  All the records are gone, but it did help to know that a faulty left tail flap mechanism caused the plane's explosion in the air. there were others in the plane who also lost their lives. I was just 8 mos old at the time; I know it changed my mother forever.  It is, as you described, agony.  I'm sorry for Kobe, his daughter, and thanks for reading out all the names of everyone who died on that helicopter.  It matters.
snippet.textOriginal: Thank you Stephen for disclosing your own loss and agony and for using your position to encourage a change to create better helicopter safety. snippet.textDisplay: There's got to be a way to improve the chances of people surviving helicopter crashes cuz right now, almost everyone dies if a chopper goes down.....like a parachute that goes up if the engine fails or a balloon that blows up underneath the chopper when it's about to crash. Something! It makes me never want to ever get on a chopper because the risk is just too great in case anything goes wrong.
snippet.textOriginal: There's got to be a way to improve the chances of people surviving helicopter crashes cuz right now, almost everyone dies if a chopper goes down.....like a parachute that goes up if the engine fails or a balloon that blows up underneath the chopper when it's about to crash. snippet.textOriginal: Wow

snippet.textDisplay: Never mind recording what goes wrong - how about singular-to-quadruple seat(s) ejection like in a fighter jet - but at a big angle downwards, detaching from the manifold and missing the blades? Or a seize-rotor with upwards ejection. Basically you'd be carried in a big detachable box with parachutes and/or rotors like a big chopper that splits into four within an air-bag/free-fall speed equivalent to +/- 500-1000 feet elevation........ ? I suppose by the time something major goes wrong it's too dangerous/impossible to just unbuckle and jump with a parachute. I recommend electric power motors like a drone, there's less moving parts and they exist today, without ejection seats probably.
snippet.textOriginal: Never mind recording what goes wrong - how about singular-to-quadruple seat(s) ejection like in a fighter jet - but at a big angle downwards, detaching from the manifold and missing the blades? Or a seize-rotor with upwards ejection. Basically you'd be carried in a big detachable box with parachutes and/or rotors like a big chopper that splits into four within an air-bag/free-fall speed equivalent to +/- 500-1000 feet elevation........ ? I suppose by the time something major goes wrong it's too dangerous/impossible to just unbuckle and jump with a parachute. I recommend electric power motors like a drone, there's less moving parts and they exist today, without ejection seats probably.

snippet.textDisplay:
Omg... I think I cried the hardest I ever have watching this and I've bawled my eyes out over my hero, Kobe. I adore Stephen too. Always have always will. I had no clue and I admire and respect his ability to share that to extend out a have of true understanding about this feeling. Obviously INCREDIBLY DIFFICULT to share that story, and that was just beautiful and selfless to do. Beautifully said. Just beautifully beautifully said.
My heart goes out to anyone who has ever had to experience this situation and may all the heavy hearts be carried by God at this time and forever more.

snippet.textDisplay: JUST BAFFLES me how these modern-day Helis don't have black boxes. That, and how they don't have that instruments where the device alerts the pilot if he is flying too low to the ground. Such a senseless death and all could've prevented if those devices were installed. I hate to say this, but it seems profit over life, which is usually the case with the flying transportation industry.

snippet.textDisplay:
Yeah so...he played sportsball real well but he was also a rapist soooooo...Not to mention the long-term bullying reported by teammates so...not sure how "great of a person" he really was off the court. I'm not saying you gotta hate him but it's hurtful to see so many people forget that his "greatness" came at a price to others.
I hope his family and the families of the others lost in the crash can heal from this monumental loss and they will be in my thoughts.
snippet.textOriginal:
Yeah so...he played sportsball real well but he was also a rapist soooooo...Not to mention the long-term bullying reported by teammates so...not sure how "great of a person" he really was off the court.  I'm not saying you gotta hate him but it's hurtful to see so many people forget that his "greatness" came at a price to others.  
I hope his family and the families of the others lost in the crash can heal from this monumental loss and they will be in my thoughts.
